Por su parte, Daniel se dedica integralmente al campo, sembrando plátanos y maíz, constituyendo otros ingresos que giran alrededor de la agricultura, ya sea para seguir sembrando o para gastos de abonos. Con su ayuda, Janet podrá obtener su préstamo número 4 de MFP, entidad de la que se siente agradecida y respaldada por la ayuda que brinda a los sectores más humildes pero progresistas. Ella y su banco comunal guardan sentimientos de confianza y gratitud. Con el dinero, Janet podrá invertir en la compra de ropa al por mayor en todas sus variedades, polos, chompas, pantalones, etc., y expenderlas en la ciudad de Pichanaki.
texts.en:
Janet is twenty five years old and lives with her partner, Daniel, and their two children, who are six and two years old. Their family lives in a rented house in the native community of Pucharini. Janet enjoys what she does, every festival day she travels to the city of Pichanaki and sells clothes that she purchases in large quantities in Lima. She also has a business with her sister who lives in Lima, and together they take care of all the purchasing and selling. Janet says, “the work is profitable because it brings in weekly earnings.” Many times, the lack of capital kept this young mother from being consistent with her business. They have not faced another time of hardship, but she is conscious that sooner or later difficult times will come.
Daniel only works in the field, planting bananas and corn, which makes other agricultural-related income, be it to continue planting or to cover fertilizer costs. With your help, Janet will be able to obtain her fourth loan from MFP [Microfinanzas Prisma]. She feels very grateful for and supported by the help MFP offers the most humble but progressive sectors. She and her communal bank feel confidence and gratitude. The money will allow Janet to purchase a wide variety of clothes wholesale – shirts, sweaters, pants, etc., and sell them in Pichanaki.
.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en: Jeanne is 40 years old and owns a butcher shop where she sells meat.  She has been in this business for more than seven years. Jeanne has requested this loan to buy cows for slaughtering. With the profits, she plans to pay school fees for the children, and provide food for the family. She dreams of seeing her business grow, so she can have her own butcher house in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cows to provide meat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy serving plates, tea cups, tea spoons, as well as food such as potatoes, onions, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit and vegetables vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 28,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell in her stall.

Evangeline has been in this business for 20 years. Evangeline earns more income from rice retailing.

Evangeline has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Nyantiop

texts.en:
Nyantiop is a 30-year-old a married woman with four children. Two of them are in school. She has a business of selling fish in Bor, South Sudan for five years.

Nyantiop requested this loan through BRAC south Sudan to purchase fish. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 25-year-old a married woman with two children; both of them are in school. She's had a business of selling fish in Yei, South Sudan for three years.

Betty is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase fish. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Awoumessi

texts.fr:
Awoumessi est une femme âgée de 54 ans. Elle est mariés å un plombier. Elle a 3 enfants.
Awoumessi travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2000. Elle vend des poissons fumés et séchés pour tous clients dans un marché de la place. Elle achète les produits au Ghana. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, n’a pas de difficultés.
Awoumessi a requis son 2nd  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des poissons fumés et séchés. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité.
Dans les prochaines années, Awoumessi voudrait agrandir la taille de son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de prendre soin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Awoumessi is a 54-year-old woman. She is married to a plumber and has three children.
Awoumessi has worked as a retailer since 2000. She sells smoked and dried fish to all types of customers at the market in her neighborhood. She buys her products in Ghana. She works by herself. Currently, she has no difficulties in her business.
Awoumessi has requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy smoked and dried fish. She wants to reinvest in her business.
In the coming years, Awoumessi would like to expand the size of her business. She says that with the profits, she intends to take care of her family.

loans.use: To buy smoked fish.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es: César, de 34 años es un hombre trabajador. Junto a Julia, su esposa desde hace 10 años; cuidan de sus 3 hijos en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad de Acostambo. “Me falta muchos objetivos por cumplir”, afirma. Aún no posee el dinero necesario para comprar sus propios terrenos agrícolas, pero eso no lo desanima al contrario. Trabaja cada día con más esfuerzo, ahorrando lo que pueda para comprar uno. Ya tiene 7 años de experiencia en la siembra de papa, olluco, oca, mashua, cebada, habas y alverja. Cuenta que alquila terrenos de su comunidad, porque cuestan menos y de esa manera apoya en el crecimiento de sus pobladores. En cada cosecha aprovecha sus viajes a la capital para vender sus alimentos. Viaja 2 veces a la semana, llevando maca, alverja y papa; los cuales vende al menudeo en el mercado “la parada”, que es la más grande del país. Como es un hombre de campo, cuenta que posee 3 caballos y 3 burros los cuales utiliza como animales de carga para trasportar los fertilizantes hacia sus sembríos. “de esa manera me canso menos”, comenta. Este es el quinto crédito con MFP y está contento de saber, que tendrá apoyo financiero, ya que se sentirá seguro de avanzar con su trabajo Por otro lado promete cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas. Además le agrada ser parte de su asociación porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias. César de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de fertilizantes naturales para esparcir entre sus cultivos de papa de la variedades “yungay, canchan, andina y huairo macho”.
texts.en:
Cesar, age 34, is a hardworking man. Together with Julia, his wife of ten years, he cares for their children in their own home, which is located in the district of Acostambo. "I have many goals to fulfill," he declares. 

Although he doesn't have the money necessary to buy his own agricultural land, he doesn't let this discourage him. Every day he puts more effort into his work, and saves what he can towards buying land. Already Cesar has seven years of experience growing potatoes, other tuber vegetables such as ulluco, oca, and mashua, barley, broad beans, and peas. He says that he rents plots of land from his community because it costs less and this way he also supports growth for its inhabitants. 

For every harvest he takes advantage of his trips to the capital to sell his crops. He travels twice a week, bringing maca, peas and potatoes, which he sells at "La parada", the largest market in the country. 

As he's a country man, he takes advantage of owning three horses and three donkeys and uses them as cargo animals to transport fertilizer to the fields. "This way I get less tired," he explains. 

This is Cesar's fifth loan with MFP, and is happy to know that he will have financial support and feels secure continuing with his work. Apart from anything else he promises to comply with his payments. Furthermore he appreciates being a part of his community bank because all of the members are responsible and supportive. 

Upon receiving the funds, Cesar will invest the money requested in the purchase of natural fertilizers to spread on his crops, which include several varieties of potato such as yungay, canchán, Andean and huario macho.

loans.use: to buy sacks of natural fertilizers.

loans.name: Suhad

texts.en:
Suhad is conservative person she is unwilling to upload her picture on the internet thus the man inthe photo is her brother.
Suhad is  a 30-year-old woman from Ashrafia, Amman, Jordan.

Suhad is looking to improve her family's living conditions by requesting a loan of 800 JD for doing maintenance on her house.

loans.use: to do maintenance on her house

loans.name: Marianela Lourdes

texts.en:
Marianela was accepted into the Universidad Mayor De San Andrés and now with the chance to achieve her dream of a professional degree is concerned about affording tuition fees. 

She plans on graduating in July 2013, but without a loan she fears that she will need to defer her graduation. Marianela plans on using the loan to cover the cost of her graduation fees. Often there are fees for earning your title in business before graduating. 

With a career in business, she expects to earn $13 a day, a substantial increase from before. With one older sibling attending college already, Marianela is unsure how she will be able to finance her education on her own without the assistance of a loan.

This loan is administered by Vittana's partner Banco Fie.

loans.use: To pay for graduation fees

loans.name: Ayitcheme 6 Group

texts.fr: AYITCHEME 6 est un groupement composé de vingt deux personnes qui sont résident dans un même quartier.  La  représentante du groupe, Augustine O. (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 34 a très peu fréquenté l’école. Augustine O. mère de deux enfants, ne vit plus avec son mari. Tous ces enfants sont scolarisés et à sa charge. Augustine O. vit seule avec ses enfants. Les diverses charges du ménage sont supportées par dame Augustine O. Pour cette raison, Augustine O. vend des des sacs de charbon à son domicile depuis dix ans. Augustine O. s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Augustine O. sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe AYITCHEME 6 un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le crédit antérieur a été bien remboursé.

loans.use: Acheter des sacs de charbon.

loans.name: Géminis Group

texts.es:
Si se busca una comunidad alegre, rica en tradiciones, amigable, rodeada de naturaleza y en donde se puede transitar con mucha tranquilidad entonces se debe viajar al Estado de México pues sin duda allí se cumplen estas características. De igual modo, las personas de dichas comunidades son muy alegres, trabajadoras y gracias a su esfuerzo han adquirido los servicios necesarios para vivir tranquilamente. 
   Doña María del Carmen, integrante del grupo Géminis, es una persona emprendedora y sumamente alegre y, ante todo, una mujer responsable con sus obligaciones. Actualmente es viuda y ninguno de sus hijos depende de ella, no obstante, desde hace 12 años se dedica a la venta de comida típica: "inicié con mi actividad porque me encanta cocinar comida de todo tipo desde española hasta china pero como aquí nos gusta más la mexicana por eso es la que cocino mucho” comenta con una gran sonrisa.  
   A través de todos sus años de experiencia ha tenido vivencias buenas y malas pero afortunadamente  han sido más los episodios favorables y hoy en día puede disfrutar de un lugar establecido en donde ofrece sus deliciosos platillos. Desde las tres de la tarde y hasta las 12 de la noche los clientes acuden a su negocio ubicado en el centro de su municipio para disfrutar de sus alimentos; su hija le ayuda a brindar el servicio característico que ha logrado que su clientela siempre regrese. 
   Dos de sus hijos terminaron sus carreras profesionales por lo que está muy contenta con su actividad y ahora sólo espera continuar solventando los gastos de su hogar y mejorar su negocio para aumentar sus clientes. 
   Por otro lado, los demás integrantes muestran el mismo agradecimiento pues las ayudas de los préstamos mejorar con creces sus negocios. Ellos son José quien invertirá en sábanas, colchas y toallas; Saturnina, en artículos para el hogar; Lidia, en cerdos; María Felisa; en reses; Erika, en ropa y Ofelia y Jessica, en ovejas.
*La fotografía fue tomada en el lugar donde se reúne el grupo, doña Carmen es quien viste el mandil blanco.

loans.use: comprara maíz, verdura, carne, jugos y refrescos

loans.name: Sasho

texts.en: Sasho I. has been a military officer for 22 years. He is 50 years old now. After he retires from the army he starts his farming business and runs it for 8 years so far. Now he breeds 23 cows and 120 sheep in his farm. In business help him his wife and his two son who is 24 and his daughter who is 22 years old. Sasho I. and his family need a milking machine for their farm and apply for a $ 2 000 loan.

loans.use: For a milking machine

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Mrs. O. L. is married to a civil servant and has two children. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She needs a loan of $900 to expand her business. She keeps very good accounts of her business and knows about the TEACH Lending program.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase dried corn stocks, for her business expansion

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.es:
Cynthia lives in the city of Santa Catarina, in the state of Nuevo Leon. She is married and has two children ages 9 and 16. She would like her children to have a quality education and improve their quality of life, which would be impossible on her husband's salary alone. For the past 10 years, Cynthia has been involved in the sale of footwear via catalog. Little by little, her business has grown and her clientele has increased.

She is now filling large orders and needs a loan of $925 which she will use to acquire merchandise to meet the demands of her customers and continue to grow. She is committed to repaying the loan in 8 months. You can become a part of this business by deciding to help this family today. They sincerely appreciate your confidence and support.

Translated from Spanish by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Cynthia vive en la localidad de Santa Catarina en el estado de Nuevo León, es casada y tiene dos hijos de 9 y 16 años de edad. Ella desea que sus hijos puedan tener una educación de calidad y mejorar su calidad de vida lo que sería imposible sólo con el salario que recibe su esposo, por lo que desde hace 10 años Cynthia se dedica a la venta de calzado por catálogo, poco a poco ha hecho crecer su negocio incrementando su número de clientes.

Ahora surte grandes pedidos y necesita de un préstamo de $ 925 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía con lo que espera cubrir la demanda de sus clientes y continuar creciendo, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en 8 meses. Tú puedes formar parte de este negocio, decídete a ayudar a esta familia hoy, ellos te agradecen sinceramente tu confianza y apoyo.

loans.use: Acquire merchandise

loans.name: Sindra

texts.en: Sindra is 26 years old, and has 3 kids, one in school and two young ones. She started her plantation business 2 years ago and now she has joined SPBD for a loan to help her and her family expand their business.  She sells her taro and bananas twice a week on Friday and Saturday, and they earn a profit of $140 a week. She uses it for family needs and other expenses but never forgets her loan repayment to SPBD every week.  Her husband earns $72 a week from his work.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and equipment

loans.name: Sahila

texts.en: Sahila is 57 years old, widowed, and lives in the Khaladj  village in the Salyan region  with her  five  children. She has run her own farm for the past 20 years and has used the income it generates to care for her family. Sahila has requested a loan of $1200 to buy pesticides and fertilizer which she will use to improve the size and quality of her crops.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. U. Pov, 44, and her husband, Bey Pich, live in a modest wood stilt home. They have five children who still live at home, in addition to two young orphaned relatives. Pov has been a weaver since she was 14 years old. It's a skill she learned from her mother. Now, she is teaching her own daughter, 19, to weave as well. They own two looms. Pich is a moto-taxi driver and operates between their Mekong island of Koh Dach and Phnom Penh.

Pov is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $300. They will use this loan to purchase materials for home repairs. The existing corrugated roof is in bad shape and much of it needs replacement. Pov says the new roof will cost $500, but that they have saved $200 already. As Pov has successfully repaid previous loans, we feel sure she will repay this new loan as well.

loans.use: Buy materials for home repair.

loans.name: Sada's Tujikomboe Group

texts.en:
Sada, 27, is married and has 3 children (ages 12, 9, and 7). She also takes care of her parents. Sada runs a food business and sells various types of dishes and snacks between 7am and 3 pm daily. She began this business in 2006 and now makes a monthly profit of about $140. She hopes to expand her business with a loan.

Sada will be sharing this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses in donuts, eggs, and other food sales. They belong to a loan group called Tujikomboe, which totals 30 members who ensure that others in the group meet their obligations.

loans.use: To increase food inventory

loans.name: Atukuzwe

texts.en:
Greetings from Mbeya, Tanzania! Atukuzwe S. is 26 years old. She is widowed with two children, ages 8 and 11. In 2004, Atukuzwe established a clothing business. Atukuzwe now requests a loan in order to purchase a motorcycle to transport her goods.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not credit worthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Rim

texts.en:
Mrs. Rim K. and her husband have been married for forty years. They have six children; two sons and four daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, and the other three have full-time employment, and the youngest one is studying.

Mrs. Rim and her husband have been doing farming for twenty years. They grow bananas, corns, and tomatoes in the farm near their home. Besides doing farming, her husband is a Khmer traditional musician. They are in early 60’s but still strong enough to work. The family lives in Mekong River’s Island about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Rim is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of $1000 for growing bananas, corns, and tomatoes.

loans.use: For growing corns, bananas, and tomatoes

loans.name: Marie Joseph

texts.fr:
Marie Joseph B., age 46, has one child and has been a member of the village bank of Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara for four years. Her business consists of selling ice and ice cream that she makes with monkey bread (baobab fruit) and sugar. Her income enables her to improve family living conditions by contributing her children's healthcare and schooling. Marie is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Marie Joseph B., 46 ans, 01 enfant est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis quatre ans. Ses activités consistent à vendre de la glace et des crèmes glaces qu'elle prépare avec le pain de de singe (fruit du baobab) et du sucre.Ses revenus lui permettent d' amélioration les conditions de vie de la famille en contribuant aux soins de santé et à la scolarité des enfants. Marie sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy sugar and monkey bread

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with 2 children, ages 22 and 18 years old. Elizabeth owns a small general store that she started in 2001. Every day, she works from 6.30am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Elizabeth has already taken out and repaid two loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To start a small business making and selling tablecloths, cushions, and window curtains.

loans.name: Temukisa

texts.en:
Temukisa T., 40, is married with 2 children and lives in Safaaoa Uta, Samoa. She has been growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas for two years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

Temukisa has a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Temukisa’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase agricultural chemicals and pesticides.

loans.use: To buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Groupement De Keur Madiagne

texts.fr:
These women have a good history with the IMCEC credit organization, dating from two years ago. They buy vegetables, fish, oil and second-hand clothes, which they resell in their neighborhoods around the village of Mbour. They are going to use this loan to augment their working capital, thereby increasing their stock and diversifying the products they carry. They are part of the large Lingueres de Mbour association. They are mothers of families, very lively and hardworking.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Elles ont une bonne expérience avec l’IMCEC (deux ans). Elles achètent des légumes, du poisson, de l’huile et de la piperie qu’elles revendent dans leurs quartiers situés à la périphérie de la commune de Mbour. Elles vont investir le crédit dans le renforcement de leur fonds de roulement et ainsi, améliorer le niveau de les stocks et la diversité de leurs produits. Elles font parti du grand groupement des Lingueres de Mbour .Elles sont des mères de familles très dynamiques et travailleuses.

loans.use: Fortification of working capital

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.ru:
Пулатова Мавлюда 1959 года рождения, замужем и у них 6 детей. У нее довольно большой опыт в сфере предпринимательской деятельности.  Начала свой бизнес в 1990 году с продажи материй. Мавлюда торгует разными видами поплин, на рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе. У нее много постоянных  клиентов. Часто покупают швеи и просто любители пошива женской одежды. Ведь ее товар является ходовым в летнее время. Свой товар Мавлюда закупает в оптовых рынках «Корвона». 
Для увеличения товарооборота и закупа сезонных тканей хочет получить займ в сумме 4100 сомони.
texts.en:
Mavluda P. was born in 1959, is married and has six children. She has quiet an extensive experience in running own business. She started her business in 1990 selling fabrics. Mavluda sells different kinds of poplins at the Kovron market in the city of Dushanbe. She has many regular customers who are often seamstresses or who just love making women's clothing. Her merchandise is very popular during summer time. Mavluda buys the merchandise on the wholesale markets of Kovron. She wants to get a loan in the amount of 4100 somoni ($1,200USD) to increase commodity circulation and for buying seasonal fabrics.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal fabrics

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily K. is 40 years old, married and has 5 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

Emily has a grinding machine which she uses to grind tomatoes, peppers, beans etc.  She needs a loan in the amount of $450 to buy another grinding machine.  This, she says, will enable her to meet the demands of her customers.

Emily thanks all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy one grinding machine

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia R. R. is a member of community bank, Llapanchik, a Quechuan word meaning “everyone together”. Sonia lives in Ayacucho with her husband and three children who are all in school. In her house, Sonia has a workshop for making dresses. 

She will use her loan of 2000 soles to purchase more sewing machines, currently her machines are rented. She will also be able to buy some fabric for her workshop. She dreams of having a larger place outside of her home for a workshop. She and her husband are also saving to start their own hardware store.
texts.en:
Sonia R. R. is a member of a Community Bank called Llapanchik, a Quechuan word meaning “everyone together”. Sonia lives in Ayacucho with her husband and three children who are all in school. In her house, Sonia has a workshop for making dresses.

She will use her loan of 2000 soles to purchase more sewing machines, currently her machines are rented. She will also be able to buy some fabric for her workshop. She dreams of having a larger place outside of her home for a workshop. She and her husband are also saving to start their own hardware store.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will use her loan of 2000 soles to purchase more sewing machines, currently her machines are rented.

loans.name: Arco Iris Group

texts.es:
El Banco D. Emprendimiento Arco Iris, fue conformado este año, gracias a la inquietúd D. algunos D. sus integrantes, quienes son familiares, y tienen negocios en común.

ELECTO S..- Es el presidente del banco comunal, el es nacido en la provincia D. VallegranD. del Departamento D. Santa Cruz. Actualmente vive en la zona D. El Torno, el vive con su hijo y su esposa en una pequeña casa propia, la cual ha sido adquirida con el fruto D. su trabajo, ellos tienen una panadería, desD. hace 20 años.

Sabina Farrel.- es la tesorera del Banco comunal, vive en la zona D. El Torno, tiene cuatro hijos y vive en casa propia. Se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos, negocio que realiza D. manera ambulante y D. la misma manera que las otras compañeras con el tiempo quiere llegar a colocar su negocio fijo.
Su esposo trabaja como ayudante D. chofer, el sueño D. ambos es llegar a contar con vehiculo propio.
texts.en:
The Rainbow Venture Bank was established this year thanks to the concern of the founders, who are family and have the business in common. Electo S.- President of the community bank. He was born in the province of VallegranD. in the Santa Cruz region. Currently, he lives in El Torno zone with his son and wife in his small home that he bought with the fruits of his labor. They have operated a bread shop for the past 20 years. Sabina Farrel- Treasurer of the community bank. She lives in the El Torno zone, has four children, and has her own house. She makes a living by selling cosmetics, a business that she realizes by traveling to people's homes in the same way as her colleagues. Her husband works as a driver. He dream is for both of them to have their own cars.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raise capital

loans.name: Juan Ramon

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Juan M. me dedico a la Sastreria, tengo un taller desde hace 11 años, poco a poco hemos contruido mi casa con nuestra madre, ahora necesitamos remodelar un cuarto y un baño para tener mejor acondicionada a nuestra mama, ella es una señora mayor de 60 años, en mi negocio me va bien y mis clientes me prefieren por la atencion que les brindo y por supuesto la ropa que les hago que les gusta mucho porque les queda muy bien tallada. el credito que solicito lo ocupo para reacondicionar nustra casa. gracias
texts.en:
Hello. My name is JuanM. and I am a tailor. I have had a shop for 11 years. Little by little we have built our home with our mother. Now we need to remodel a room and bathroom in order to better accommodate our mother, as she is a 60 year old older woman. My business is going very well and my customers prefer my services for the attention I provide and of course they like the clothing that I make them a lot because it fits them very well. The loan I am seeking will be used to remodel our home. Thank you.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to remodel a room and bathroom

loans.name: Karam

texts.en: Karam K. is a very optimistic man in spite of the circumstances he has endured. He is 51 years old and married with four children. Karam raises livestock, and he uses his income to support his family’s expenses. He has a great appreciation for animals and Karam wishes to increase his sheep count, and therefore increase his earnings. He hopes that you can help him by funding his loan. You could become an important part of his family's life. Karam deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: Purchase 10 sheep

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is 40 years old. She is widowed with six children. The eldest is a commercial driver, one child is a  hairdresser and the rest are still in junior high school. Rose is a local manufacturer of palm oil and has sold fruits like bananas and oranges for the past eight years to take care of her family. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruit. The palm oil is processed through various stages to obtain the palm oil.  Palm oil is used to prepare many local dishes. Her production is on a small scale due to lack of capital to buy machines for the processing.

In addition to the palm oil business, she also sells fruits like banana and oranges etc. in the community where she lives. She says this has also slowed down due to current food prices in the world market. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm nuts to increase her efficiency and produce in larger quantities. She wants the loan to purchase bananas and oranges etc. so that she can produce daily and supply to her customers on regular bases.

Rose believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to provide food and finance her children's education. Rose belongs to a village bank called Chance. She hopes to receive GH¢700 to make her business grow by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts, fruits, bananas, and oranges to restock her inventory.

loans.name: Carmina

texts.es:
Después de una vida trabajando brindando servicios de casa, a sus cuarenta y ocho años y desde hace un año, Carmina se animó a abrir una tienda de dulces, abarrotes y gaseosas. Eso fue principalmente gracias a sus hijas que le aconsejaron que ya había pasado demasiado tiempo haciendo estos trabajos de casa que son muy exigentes físicamente y que a largo plazo le pudieran generar graves problemas de salud. 
Carmina ayuda su negocio y el de su cónyuge con los préstamos de EDAPROSPO desde hace ocho meses, y ambos juntan sus ganancias para cubrir los gastos del hogar y de sus dos hijitas de catorce y once años, juntos se encargan también de pagar las mensualidades de los préstamos.
En un futuro a Carmina le gustaría agrandar su tienda hasta convertirla en un mini-mercado, especializándose en todo lo que es gaseosas, cervezas y dulces, ya que estos son los productos con los cuales se gana más y a diferencia de los abarrotes, no se malogran. 
De cualquier modo, antes de invertir mucho más en su negocio quiere invertir en la educación de sus hijas, y cuando ya ellas hayan acabado de estudiar dedicar todas sus inversiones a su negocio.
texts.en:
After a life of housekeeping, a year ago, at the age of 48, Carmina opened a store selling sweets, groceries, and soft drinks. That was mainly thanks to her daughters, who advised her that she had already spent too much time doing physically demanding work in people's homes which could lead to long-term health problems. Carmina has supported her business and that of her husband through loans from EDAPROSPO for the past eight months. Both of them have pooled their incomes to cover the expenses of their home and their 14- and 11-year-old daughters. Together, they also make the monthly repayments on their loans. In the future, Carmina would like to expand her store into a mini-mart, specializing in soft drinks, beer and sweets, as these are the products she profits most from, and unlike groceries, they don't spoil. At any rate, before she invests much more in her business, she wants to invest in her daughters' education, and once they have completed their studies she will invest everything in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest part in her store, and the rest in her husband's recycling business

loans.name: Jameda

texts.en: Jameda A. is married and has 6 dependents. She has received schooling through tertiary education. Jameda sells pastries at Abura, which she has done since 1994. Her husband is an accountant. Jameda uses her income to assist her husband in paying the household expenses. Jameda will use the loan to increase her stock of flour and other ingredients to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She plans to reinvest the new profits back into her business.

loans.use: For stocks of ingredients to increase bakery output

loans.name: Safarali

texts.en:
D. Safarali has been in the livestock business for many years. He supports his wife and four children. Since he began his business, he has worked hard to use his earnings to sustain his home. His livestock business has helped him to achieve his goals.

Currently, Safarali needs to purchase more livestock in order to grow his business and improve the living conditions of his family. He is seeking a loan from IMON International in order to acquire additional animals to offer in the markets.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Emanuel

texts.en: Emanuel N. is a Tanzanian small-business owner. He is married and runs a business selling soft drinks in his grocery in the  Yombo Vituka ward of Dar es Salaam. His sells a variety of soft drinks, including Coca-Cola products, Pepsi products, sterilized drinking water and juices. He purchases the business items from wholesale shops and from Coca-Cola and Pepsi agents. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Bilikisu

texts.en:
Bilikisu is 36 years old and married with four children. She has a shop where she sells shoes, clothes, gift items and bags.

She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Umbrella Of Komeh Avenue Group

texts.en:
This is Abdul J. K., Aminata K. and Musa L.. They called their group “Umbrella of Komeh Avenue”. This will be the third time these entrepreneurs are seeking a loan from Kiva lenders. Previously, each one of them received Le 600,000 which they have successfully repaid with ease.

Now, they are requesting a new loan of Le 800,000 for each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses. This will help them a lot. It will enable them make more profit and improve their standard of living.

Abdul (left) is the leader of this group. Abdul was born in the town of Magburaka, fifteen miles from Makeni City, in northern Sierra Leone. He is forty-one years of age, and married with six children. One of his children is in a teachers training college and the others are in secondary schools.

Abdul sells medicines and owns an Okada (a motorbike used as a taxi). He will invest this loan in his pharmacy. He has been a businessman for over twenty-two years now.

loans.use: To invest in his pharmacy

loans.name: Nonelyn

texts.en:
Nonelyn R. is from the town of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Nonelyn is married to Theddy and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Nonelyn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nonelyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nonelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nonelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase grocery items for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nonelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for sale

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Mrs. M., a 34-year-old single mother of two children, ages eight and four years, lives in a neighborhood called "villa Petrolero" where she rents three rooms (kitchen, bedroom and living room). Her husband left her some years ago, so she was forced to start her own business buying and selling jewelry for women (bijouterie). She sometimes travels to the Peruvian frontier where she buys the merchandise which she sells later in Cochabamba, making a small profit. Mrs. M. has some competition since there are other stores and street vendors who are in the same business, but she has managed to occupy a small shop near the University where she can sell her products to the students.

Mrs. M. will use her loan from Agrocapital to paint and furnish the small store she has, and she is intending to acquire a new shop that will be located in a market known for handicrafts and tourist souvenirs near the downtown. The last loan she obtained from Agrocapital was paid with no delays; she’s an excellent client and we are ready to support her in any new venture.

loans.use: Painting and furnishing her store.

loans.name: Fatou A

texts.fr: Fatou C. est une femme mariée et s’active dans la vente de mangues. Elle souhaiterait avec ses revenus améliorer une meilleure vie à sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou C. is a married woman and is active in selling mangoes. She would like to use her revenues to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in fruit, such as mangoes

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in KInyanambo,Iringa,she is 35 years old,she is married and a mother of 1 child.Her child is 2 years aged.

Zaina started her own business selling local beer 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 60,000Tanzania shillings.

This is Zaina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more Maize for local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Zaina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for local beer

loans.name: La Inmaculada (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal La Inmaculada se encuentra en un lugar muy hermoso de la provincia del Cañar, se trata de las ruinas arqueológicas de Inga pirca, es una ciudad de piedra que nuestros Incas construyeron formando allí su fortaleza, también tienen labrado la cara de un inca en la montaña es un lugar muy hermoso que es visitado todo el tiempo por turistas nacionales y extranjeros, nuestras socias se encuentran muy contentas por haber heredado su cultura, tradiciones y por la importancia de llevar en sus vidas cotidianas todo el honor y el orgullo que Inga Pirca representa.

El Banco Comunal  La Inmaculada está formado por un grupo de 10 integrantes hombres y mujeres dispuestas a superarse y surgir poco a poco hacia delante, aquí algunos testimonios.

La  Sra. Esther Yolanda L. P., es socia del Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, vive en Inga Pirca perteneciente a la provincia del Cañar, tiene 22 años de edad, y vive en unión libre con su pareja  hace un año, tiene 3 hijos: de 6, 4, 1,5 de edad, su primer hijo se encuentra en la escuela de la comunidad, no tienen casa propia, viven en la casa de un familiar que les presta por un tiempo, su esposo trabaja como chofer y le apoya en todo, siendo el pilar en su vida, dice.
 
Esther trabaja como empleada domestica en el centro de la ciudad, y  en el poco  tiempo que tiene en  su casa a la crianza de pollos y cuyes,

Este es su primer crédito y le interesa los beneficios que obtiene siendo socia de la Fundación Espoir; con el préstamo que esta realizando va ha iniciar su galpón de pollos, para así dejar de trabajar para otras personas y dedicarse solamente a sus hijos y negocio, su sueño es llegar a tener su casa propia.

La Sra. Mariana de Jesús V. es socia del Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, vive en el barrio Santa Bárbara en la parroquia Santa Ana a unos 40 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 43 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 5 hijos,  de: 22, 19, 14, 6, y 3 meses de edad, sus dos primeros hijos no son reconocidos por su padre y ya  tienen propio hogar, sus otros tres  hijos son reconocidos pero su padre pero no les ayuda en nada;  su hijo de 14 años es quien muchas veces se encarga de la casa hasta que Mariana llegue del trabajo, viven en una casa propia de adobe, es una ventaja acota.

Mariana trabaja como empleada domestica en el centro de la ciudad, también  se dedica a la crianza de  pollos y cuyes,  los alimenta antes de ir y regresar del trabajo

Es su primer crédito y,  se entero de los beneficios y oportunidades de la Fundación ESPOIR gracias a una amiga que le invito a ser parte del banco comunal. Con el dinero del crédito solicitado  va a poner un criadero de pollos para tener un negocio propio y así ir mejorando su calidad de vida y sacar a su familia adelante como lo ha hecho hasta ahora

Su sueño es de llegar a tener una casa de ladrillo para vivir cómodamente sin preocuparse del invierno, darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.

La Sra. Martha Adriana L. es otra  socia  del banco comunal La Inmaculada, vive en Inga Pirca en un lugar muy hermoso de las tierras Cañarenses, tiene 21 años de edad, vive en unión libre y fruto de su amor procreo 2 hijos de 3 y 1,5 años de edad, tienen una relación consolidada de 5 años y se llevan muy bien, su esposo trabaja en la construcción y viven en casa propia.

Martha trabaja como empleada domestica  de lunes a viernes,  y los fines de semana se dedica a su negocio, tiene un criadero de cerdos, pollos y cuyes, aunque estos últimos se le murieron y ahora está tratando de recuperarse de esa pérdida, también sacrifica un cerdo sea de su criadero o comprado y con ello elabora ornado  o vende la carne cruda por libras, nos dice que la va muy bien en la venta!!.

Este es su primer crédito y se siente muy contenta de haber ingresado al banquito porque sabe que tiene buenos  beneficios  que la fundación ofrece y por las socias que son muy amigas en la comunidad y están dispuestas a superarse

El préstamo que está realizando lo va a invertir en la compra de cerdos para su criadero.

Su meta es llegar a tener una tienda porque son muy escasas en la comunidad y dedicarse solo a sus negocios  y así tener más tiempo para cuidar de sus hijos.
texts.en:
The communal bank "La Inmaculada" is located in a beautiful place in Cañar province in the ruins of Inga Pirca, which is a city made of stone that the Inca built as their fortress. There is also a stone face carved in a mountain by the Inca. It is a beautiful place that is always visited by local and international tourists. Our members are happy to have inherited the culture and traditions of the Inca, and they carry the honor and the pride of Inga Pirca in their daily lives.

The communal bank "La Inmaculada" is formed by a group of 10 men and women, who are all ready to overcome and move forward little by little. We have some of their stories here.

Esther Yolanda L. P. is a member of the bank She lives in Inga Pirca, and is 22 years old. She has lived with a partner for one year. She has three children who are 6, 4, and 1 year old. Her first son is in the community school. They do not have their own home; they live in a house that a family member is lending them for a while. Her husband is a chauffeur, and supports her in everything. She says he is a pillar in her life.

Esther works as a domestic employee in the city center, and in the little time that she has at home, she raises chickens and guinea pigs.

This is her first loan, and she is interested in the benefits she can receive as a member of the Espoir Foundation. With this loan she is going to start a chicken coop, so that she can stop working for other people and dedicate herself to her children and her business. Her dream is to have her own home.

Mariana de Jesús V. lives in the Santa Bárbara neighborhood in the Santa Ana parish, 40 minutes outside of Cuenca. She is 43 years old, and is the single mother of 5 children who are 22, 19, 14, 6, 3 months. The first two are not recognized by their father and have their own home. The younger three are recognized by their father, but he does not help them with anything. Her 14-year-old son often takes care of the house until Mariana comes home from work. They live in their own adobe house, which is an advantage.

Mariana works as a domestic employee in the center of the city. She also raises chickens and guinea pigs, which she feeds before and after work.

This is her first loan. She learned about the benefits and opportunities of the Espoir Foundation thanks to a friend who invited her to be part of the communal bank. With the loan, she will get a chicken hatchery so she can have her own business and improve the quality of life of her family, to help them move forward like she has been doing.

Her dream is to have a brick house, so they can live comfortably without worrying about the winter, and give her children a better life.

Martha Adriana L. is another member of the bank. She lives in Inga Pirca, in a beautiful place in the Cañar area. She is 21 years old, and lives with her partner of five years, and they get along very well. She has two children, who are 3 and 1 and a half. Her husband works in construction, and they have their own home.

Martha is a domestic employee from Monday to Friday. On weekends she works on her business. She raises pigs, chickens, and guinea pigs, although her guinea pigs recently died. Now she is trying to recover from that loss. She also slaughtered a pig from her farm, and she sold the raw meat by the pound. She says that sales are good.

This is her first loan, and she feels happy to have entered this little bank, because she knows the benefits that the foundation offers, and the members are friends in the community and are ready to overcome.

This loan will be invested in pigs for her farm.

Her goal is to have a store, because there are few in her community, and to be able to only run her business so she can have more time to care for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals (pigs, chickens, guinea pigs)

loans.name: Elvis

texts.es:
Elvis tiene 20 años y desde niño vio y aprendió de su padre la elaboración de bellos trajes típicos de su región a base de diversas aplicaciones (mostacillas, lentejuelas) y bordados únicos. Hoy, este oficio le sirve para ser independiente, pues desde hace 2 años viene elaborando estos trajes para las fiestas populares de los pueblos aledaños de su zona y en algunas ocasiones trabaja con su padre para elaborar trabajos especiales. La clave de su negocio está en su creatividad y en los bonitos diseños que crea, pues así tiene la opción de poner un precio a sus prendas que cubran su inversión y horas de trabajo.
Es la tercera oportunidad que solicita un crédito con MFP y tiene muchas ganas de seguir  trabajando por el fortalecimiento de su grupo. El dinero que ahora requiere será invertido en la compra de materiales textiles, como hilos y telas de diversos colores y texturas.
texts.en:
Elvis is 20 years old. Since he was a child he saw and learned from his father how to make beautiful clothing typical of his region. He used different embellishments (beads, sequins) and unique embroidery. Today this trade has made him independent. For two years he has been making these clothes for festivals that are popular in the towns in the outskirts of his region. Sometimes he works with his father on special jobs. The key to his business is his creativity and the beautiful designs that he creates. This way he has the option of putting a price on his clothes that cover his investment and his hours of work. This is his third opportunity to ask for a loan with MFP. He has a great desire to keep working to strengthen his group. The money that he now needs is to buy textile materials like thread and different colors and textures of fabric.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy textile materials

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda L., who lives in the village of Buenavista Sibong, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental, is 40 years old, married, and the mother of two daughters who are 8 and 12 years old. Emelda dreams of securing the future of her family and lifting them out of poverty by giving her daughters an education, sending them to earn college degrees when they grow up. She is very optimistic that she will achieve this goal because her daughters excel in school - both earning first honors in the past year.

At first, only her husband was engaged in selling “Balut” around their community, neighboring villages and the nearby towns, but even with his best efforts, his income could not provide for everything that the family needs. Since "Balut" is such a popular Filipino snack, Emelda knew that if she helped her husband and sold "Balut" in other places, she'd would earn an income, and this is what she did. When she was able to save enough, she put up a small general store adjacent to her house, but she also continued with her "Balut" vending.

When she needed fresh capital to expand her business, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005. She reciprocates the support provided by NWTF-PD by paying back her weekly installments on time and paying the loan in full within the set loan term. Emelda has continuously maintained her good credit standing, and the loans she takes help her increase her income potential. Her present average monthly income is PHP 9,000, which enables her to save for her daughters' future education.

For her previous loan, her twelfth, she borrowed Php 10,000 as additional capital for her “Balut” business. Now that she has fully repaid that loan within its term, she plans to take another loan of PHP 13,000 for her 13th cycle loan which she plans to use to purchase additional inventory and working capital for her business. She intends to use the income from this loan to continue supporting the household expenses and the education of her daughters.

Emelda is shown in the picture posing inside her general store with some of the "balut" eggs.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a mere $1 a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory and working capital for her Balut business

loans.name: Fatama Group

texts.en:
Fatama is the group leader of the Fatama Group. There are three members in this group. Each of them has business expansion goals she wishes to meet. For this reason, the four women have requested a group loan in the amount of 30,000 Afghani.

- Fatama wants to take out a loan for her husband, who owns a general store.

- Gul Sohom wants to apply her loan toward her son's tailoring business.

- Halima would like to use her loan for her carpet-weaving business.

All the members of this group are very happy to have the opportunity to request these loans from Kiva lenders, who can support all entrepreneurs around the world.

loans.use: For the expansion of the members' individual businesses

loans.name: Nen

texts.en: Nen K., 37, is married and lives with her five children in Takeo province. She stays at home making and selling cow bells to sell in the local market, and earns less than $1 USD per day. Her husband is a middle man who sells motorbikes, and also a motor-taxi driver. He typically makes about $5 USD per day. Nen K. would like a loan of $700 USD for her husband to replace his old motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 32-year-old divorced mother of three children, all currently in school. She sponsors the children's education, health care, food, etc. by herself through her cake-baking business, which she has operated for about a year. She acquired her baking skills from her late aunt. In addition to supplying her regular customers, Mercy sells through hawking in the community market where she lives.

Because she promotes good customer relations, she has many customers; she is now requesting loan to procure additional stock such as flour, flavor, nut milk, eggs, baking powder etc. Mercy believes sales will increase as we enter Christmas, and she would be grateful for the assistance Kiva lenders can provide.

loans.use: To buy items like flour, flavor, nut milk, eggs, baking powder etc.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda D. C. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old. Rosalinda is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen Q. is a 43-year-old married woman who lives in Hacienda Minahan, Brgy Odiong, La Castillana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running a general store and selling ready-to-wear clothes.

Helen’s husband helps her in the business, and they have three children who are between 10 to 16 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Helen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store and ready-to-wear clothes. Now, she earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000 from her business activities.

Helen is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 16,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 13th loan in the amount of Php 18,000, which she intends to use on ready-to-wear clothes. Helen is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon; (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon" -- a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Liza's Group

texts.en:
Liza R. is from the village of Tabbaruk, San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 49 years-old. Liza is the leader of a ten member group loan offered by Kiva partner ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Liza is widowed and has two adult children. Liza owns and operates a general store which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 500 PHP a day.

In 2008, Liza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Liza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and North-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Canastito Group

texts.es:
El grupo Canastito está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras. La coordinadora de este grupo es la señora Rosa Adela T. C.. Ella comenzó con la venta de platanitos hace 9 años en la actualidad T. hace y distribuye platanitos a los vendedores.  

Su compañera María de los Ángeles D. G. hace ropa típica como blusas, cotonas, guayaberas, trajes de folklor etc. desde hace seis años. Mientras Teresa del Carmen R. en el 2005 decidió tener su propio negocio en el cual consiste en hacer ropa de cama y de niños.
texts.en:
The group Canastito is made up of three hard working women. Mrs. Rosa Adela T. C. is the coordinator of this group. She began selling plantains 9 years ago, and currently she prepares and distributes plantains to vendors. Her partner, Maria de los Angeles Davila Garcia, has been making typical clothing such as blouses, aprons, shirts, suits, etc. for six years. Meanwhile, in 2005, Teresa del Carmen R. decided to start her own business in which she makes bedclothes and childrens' clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make plantains

loans.name: Inqilab

texts.en:
Inqilab M. is a 46-year-old entrepreneur who sells cell phones and cell phone accessories in his own store in his home city of Agsu. He is married and has two children.

Inqilab has ten years of experience in his business. He is very friendly with his customers and that’s why he is very successful in his business.

Demand is this business is very high and the range of cell phones is changing every month, so Inqilab tries to bring in the best and newest cell models. Now he applied for 1,600 AZN to bring in new cell phones. He and his family count on your help.

loans.use: To purchase more cell phones

loans.name: N'taa

texts.en: N’taa K. is 46 years old. She works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo, selling a local beverage called tchoukoutou made from fermented millet. She began this business in 2006 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use these funds to purchase the necessary ingredients to make this drink and sell to her community. Ms. K. is not married and does not have children. Please help her keep her customers happy and hydrated.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients to make a local beverage

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Margarita pertenece al Banco Comunal “Kantu san Jerónimo” de la Asociación Arariwa, tiene 42 años, es conviviente y vive en la ciudad del Cusco. Margarita tiene cuatro hijos de la cuales los cuatro dependen de ella y ellos se llaman, Yesenia, Danilo, Linda y Chaska. Margarita es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora que se las ingenio para abrir su propio negocio de sastrería y así de esta manera sacar profesionales a sus hijos. La socia con mucha pena nos cuenta que tuvo un accidente hace dos años atrás le cayo la maquina de coser que le fracturo el pie pero actualmente se esta rehabilitando. Ya son nueve años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone y al esfuerzo de salir adelante a pesar de las adversidades. Margarita requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital de negocio  y desea comprar hilos y materiales de costura y tela. Su mayor anhelo de Margarita es tener una tienda de costura mas grande y abrir otra tienda donde pueda vender comestibles.             

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our member Margarita belongs to the communal bank “Kantu san Jerónimo” in the Arariwa Association. She is 42, in a common-law marriage and lives in the city of Cusco. Margarita has four children and they are all her dependents. They are named: Yesenia, Danilo, Linda and Chaska. Margarita is a hardworking entrepreneur who had the good sense to open her own tailoring business to be able to have her children become professionals. This member tells us sadly that two years ago she had an accident when a sewing machine fell on her and fractured her foot, but she is getting better. She has been working in this business for the past nine years and it has gone very well thanks to her hard work and push to get ahead despite the adversities. Margarita needs a loan to increase her business capital and she wishes to buy thread, sewing materials and cloth. Her biggest dream is to have a bigger tailoring shop and to open a store where she can sell groceries. The member is grateful for the opportunity offered her this way and she promises to make all the payments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Margaria needs a loan to buy thread, cloth, and materials for sewing

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 32 and married with one child. She lives and farms in Likuyani in Eldoret. She also has a hotel which helps to increase the family's income.

She came to know about KADET through her friend who is also a KADET client. She has been in farming for three years and with the loan she plans to buy maize seedlings and herbicides. Emily’s goal is to improve and enlarge the scale of her farm business.

loans.use: To buy maize seedlings and herbicide

loans.name: Delmy Jaquelina

texts.es:
la sra. Delmy Jaquelina P. B. tiene 43 años de edad, vive en la colonia el Barquito en la ciudad de Choluteca. Delmy se dedica a la venta de golosinas como ser tacos, enchiladas, baleadas, tortillas con quesillo etc. tambien vende refrescos, jugos y agua en bote y en bolsa.
dice sentirse muy feliz ya que su negocio esta creciendo poco a poco cada dia.
el prestamo lo va a utilizar para comprar materia prima para hacer las golosinas, comprar refrescos, jugos y agua. una de las cosas que mas vende son los refrescos ya que Choluteca es una ciudad muy caliente y muchas personas compran refrescos para saciar la sed.
las ganancias que obtenga las necesita para cubrir con los gastos de su hogar.
texts.en:
Delmy Jaquelina P. B., 43, lives in Choluteca’s El Barquito neighborhood; she sells snacks like tacos, enchiladas, baleadas (wheat flour tortilla, often quite thick, folded in half and filled with mashed fried beans), tortillas with quesillo (a cottage cheese-like cheese), etc. She also sells soft-drinks, juices, water in cans and plastic bags. She states that she is very happy because her business grows a little every day. She will use the funds to buy ingredients to make the snacks as well as soft-drinks, juices and water. One of her highest-selling items is the soft-drinks because the weather in Choluteca is very warm and many people buy soft-drinks to quench their thirst. Profits obtained will be used to cover household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft-drinks, juices, water, tortillas, beans, quesillo (similar to cottage cheese), lard, cooking oil, salt, spices, meats, cheeses, potatoes and vegetables.

loans.name: Nicaragua Group

texts.es:
El grupo Nicaragua está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Isabel Cristina G. R. quien se dedica a la realización de nacatamales, platillo típico a base de maíz, carde de cerdo, arroz, papa etc.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Meralia R. G. vende calzado en sandalias y zapatos y Angelia María Ríos G.
texts.en:
The group Nicaragua is comprised of three hard-working women. One of them is Isabel Cristina G. R., who dedicates herself to making nacatamales, a local food made from corn, pork, rice, potato, etc. Her companions in the group are Meralia R. G., who sells sandals and shoes, and Angelia María Ríos G..

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients, particularly corn, pork, potatoes and rice.

loans.name: Chhit

texts.en:
Mrs. K. currently earns a daily income by purchasing and selling used goods. She and her husband always leave their house in the early morning to collect and buy used goods from people who live around the community. They also save up many hundreds of kilograms of goods before selling.

The couple are the good parents of two kids who are going to high school. K. has borrowed a loan in order to accrue financial capital for her used goods selling business.

loans.use: To accrue financial capital for used goods selling business.

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza M. lives in the village of Medina in Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Feliza runs a sari-sari (or variety) shop where she sells food and other items used daily by people in her community. She has been in this line of work for more than two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Feliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid three previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to buy new items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to support her family. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Sara

texts.es: Sara, de 41 años, es madre soltera, tiene 2 hijos pero sólo vive con la menor, puesto que su hijo mayor, trabaja de manera independiente en otra localidad, en busca de un futuro mejor. Anteriormente se dedicaba en la venta de prendas de vestir,  pero ahora se dedica a atender a la menor de sus hijas. Solo los fines de semana, trabaja en su pequeño puesto de venta de comida, en donde prepara diferentes tipos de  potajes al gusto de sus clientes. Lleva 7 años trabajando en varios negocios y siempre le ha resultado muy rentable. Disfruta mucho cocinar platillos típicos de la zona selva del Perú, es por eso que más adelante, quiere tener su propio restaurante, espacio que acondicionará dentro de su casa, asimismo desea reabrir una tienda de zapatos, zapatillas y prendas de vestir sencillas, para vender al por mayor y menor. Esta es la séptima vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y está contenta de laborar en su grupo comunal, porque le enseñan a ahorrar, además todos sus integrantes son muy responsables. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará los insumos necesarios para preparar comida.
texts.en:
Sara is 41 years old and a single mother of two children. Only the younger child lives at home, while the older child is currently working in another town in efforts to create a better future for herself. Sara used to work selling dresses, but now she spends her time taking care of her younger daughter. She currently works selling food during the weekends, and makes different stews for her customers. She has spent the past 7 years working in various businesses, which have always been profitable. She enjoys cooking typical rural Peruvian food, which is why she would like to have her own restaurant in the future. For this reason Sara would like to re-start selling shoes and dresses. This is her 7th loan with MFP, and she enjoys working with her communal group because they teach each other how to save and be responsible. With this loan Sara will buy ingredients necessary for her food.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and prepare food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Carla Ninosca

texts.es:
Karla de 37 años de edad es soltera, tiene 2 hijos, trabaja para la Alcaldia Muncipal de Juigalpa desde hace 10 años, desempeñandose como  Resp. Depto. Fiscalizacion. 

Esta solicitando  su 1er credito con el objetivo de construir un anexo en su vivienda para poder brindarle mayor comodidad a su familia. 

Su mayor sueño es poder ir poco a poco acondicionando su casa ya que es el patrimonio que dejara a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Karla is 37 years old, single, and has two children. She has worked the past ten years for the City of Juigalpa as an auditor.

She is requesting her first loan to build an extension to her home in order to provide greater comfort for her family. Her greatest wish is to gradually renovate her house so that she can leave it as an inheritance for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build an extension to her house

loans.name: Idriss

texts.en:
Idriss is married with three children, two of whom are school-going. He has a shop in the city center where he sells tailoring materials. He is assisted by his wife at the shop when he is out of town.

Idriss would like a loan of 4,000,000 SLL in order to increase his tailoring material stock. His materials are in very high demand and he would very much like to satisfy his customers.

Idriss plans to use the proceeds from this loan to complete the payment for a piece of land on which he has already made a part payment. He also hopes this loan will enable him to grow his business so that he can support his family. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more clothing material to sell

loans.name: Agali Awamu Kikajjo Group-Kampala

texts.en:
The long and short term odds for success in most new businesses are dependent on many factors, but for 26-year-old M. Erid those odds have been improved because of a wealth of confidence, good blueprint planning and lots of good will from close friends. These factors have helped her to break new ground in her six-year-old beauty salon business in Namasuba-Kampala. 

She has been unrelentingly hard-working over the course of these years, and her husband has also been at her beck and call. This has helped her a great deal. Erid and her husband have one child. Her customers range from old to young women who reside in Namasuba - a growing suburban area in its own right.  

Erid says she will be empowered by this loan to buy weavers and driers for her salon. She says this will be a springboard for making more profits for her business, as her workers will be able to expedite the work that they do.

loans.use: The purchase of weavers and driers for her salon

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es: Violeta, de 41 años, vive en su casa que es propia en compañía de su esposo Héctor de 41 años, que trabaja como operario en una empresa, y de sus 2 hijos menores, juntos habitan un populoso barrio que esta ubicado al norte de la ciudad. Cada día es de constante trabajo para esta empeñosa mujer; pues no descansa y siempre busca que ayudar a su esposo con los constantes gastos del hogar. Desde hace 1 año instaló en una pieza de su casa el negocio de alquiler de videojuegos, y ahora tiene muchos clientes entre niños y jóvenes que gustan de este tipo de juegos para entretenerse, además  para la atención de este negocio cuenta con la ayuda de uno de sus hijos que lo administra, mientras ella se dirige a trabajar como niñera en una guardería de niños cercana a su casa. Por la labor de cuidar niños recibe un sueldo que le permite comprarse sus gustos; y como si fuera poco también se dedica durante su tiempo libre a la costura de pedrería en diferentes prendas de vestir; y en este negocio trabaja con un intermediario que le deja las prendas y luego le paga cuando las devuelve terminadas. Y como es una mujer muy emprendedora para mas adelante tiene planeado mejorar las instalaciones de su negocio de alquiler de videojuegos, para mejorar sus ganancias. Es el sétimo crédito que tiene con MFP, y promete pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, pues esta muy agradecida con todas las personas que hicieron posible el crédito que le permitirá continuar trabajando en busca del progreso. Violeta tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de una máquina más que necesita para implementar mejor  su negocio de alquiler de  videojuegos, de esta manera espera aumentar la cantidad de clientela que recibe a diario.
texts.en:
Violeta, 41, lives in her own house with her husband, Héctor, 41, who’s employed in a firm as an operator, and their two minor children in a densely populated neighborhood in the north of the city. Every day is a day of constant work for this dedicated woman. She never rests and always looks for ways to help her husband meet household expenses. A year ago she set up a videogame business in one of the rooms in her house. She has a lot of customers, mostly children and youngsters, who like to amuse themselves with these kinds of games. One of her children runs the business while she works as a child care provider at a day care center near her home. The child care job pays her a salary sufficient for her personal needs. If this weren’t enough, she also works attaching beadwork to articles of clothing. In this job, she works with a middleman who leaves the items of clothing with her and then pays her when she delivers the finished products. Since she’s a very enterprising woman, she plans for later in the future to improve the set up in the videogames business in order to improve her profits. This is her 7th loan with MFP and she pledges to repay on time because she is very grateful to all the persons who make the loan that will allow her to continue working towards progress possible.
